description: From Middle English godmoder, from Old English godmōdor (“godmother”), equivalent to god +‎ mother. Cognate with Old High German gotmuoter (“godmother”), Old Norse guðmóðir (“godmother”), Icelandic guðmóður (“godmother”), Swedish gudmoder (“godmother”), Danish gudmor (“godmother”).

entries.meaning: A woman present at the christening of a baby who promises to help raise the child in a Christian manner; a female godparent who sponsors the baptism of a child.

verbs.description: godmother (third-person singular simple present godmothers, present participle godmothering, simple past and past participle godmothered)

examples: The servants took to her – as they say – she godmothered three Susans during her rule, the coachman's, the gardener's and the Up Hill gamekeeper's.
